content.intro:
Fed by ocean breezes and almost 400 years of history, the capital of Massachusetts gives travellers no shortage of reasons to put down their suitcases and stay awhile. Forward-thinking and cosmopolitan yet with all the charm and atmosphere of the Old World, Boston is a vibrant gateway to America.

For some inexplicable reason, Boston, just 300 kilometres from New York, immortalised by Dennis Lehane's crime novels and the Oscar-winner feature Spotlight, is unjustly neglected by travellers. Yet the roots of America run deeper here than anywhere else in the country. The largest city in New England, it's just a short hop from where the Mayflower docked in 1630. From the Boston Tea Party to the reading of the Declaration of Independence, the fight for women's rights to the civil rights movement, Boston is the crucible in which today's United States was forged. Walking the Freedom Trail, a four-kilometre circuit from the charming gas-lit streets of Beacon Hill to the huge port, will acquaint you with many of the key spots where this tumultuous history unfolded and bring you face to face with monuments dear to the hearts of all Americans.

One of the city's dominant myths lies in three letters: JFK. Boston was the birthplace of the 35th president of the United States, and the city abounds in his shrines, from the JFK Library to the Omni Parker House Hotel, where he proposed to Jackie. This grand hotel is famous for another reason: the city's star dessert, the Boston Cream Pie. For Boston knows how to preserve its gastronomic traditions. Its oyster bars are world famous, not only for the oysters but also for lobster and local seafood, and, of course, New England Clam Chowder. More adventurous restaurants in the city are reinventing the culinary landscape, and contributing to its modern multicultural identity.

From the islands of Boston Harbor, caressed by sun and sea breeze, to the concept stores and chic trattorias in its urban areas, the good life of the city is ineluctably connected to the ocean. Its rolling surf, so beloved by JFK, has brought to these shores people from around the world. The most elegant addresses uptown coexist with Chinatown and the Italian and Irish enclaves in North End, while the old red brick factories of South End have been remodelled into hip eateries and boutiques. This attractive melting pot is reflected in the eclectic yet harmonious architecture of Boston, which spans four centuries. It is equally reflected in its rich cultural scene, which includes some of the finest museums in the world and a year-round calendar chock-a-block with rock, pop, and jazz concerts.

This perceptible effervescence owes much to the universities in Cambridge: Harvard, the oldest in the country; and MIT, which puts Boston at the forefront of the high-tech digital world. The country's future is being built here, in a city that cultivates excellence at all levels.

content.title: A stroll with a scent at the Boston Public Market

introduction.small: What say you of a foodie stroll amid one of the most popular public markets in Massachusetts?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A stroll with a scent at the Boston Public Market

paragraphs.text:
The Boston Public Market is a huge covered space where, all year long, lovers of fresh and local products gather to buy from 35 craftsmen and producers from New England. A true community nerve centre, the market brings together farmers, fishermen, businessmen, clients and partners from all around the world. They are bound by the same interest in meat, produce, dairy products, seafood and other specialities all locally sourced.

Between two daydreams about food, join workshops, cooking lessons and guided tours. For more than two decades now, they have been fuelling conversations and reflections on public health and the impact of our food habits. This educative dynamic was awarded on several occasions already!

Note that the Boston Public Market is open all week; Monday to Saturday from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m., and Sunday from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.

Boston Public Market
100 Hanover Street
Boston, MA 02108

+1 617 973 4909

content.title: Eastern mezze to be shared at Sarma

introduction.small: At Sarma, in Somerville, near Boston, small plates full of Turkish and Mediterranean flavours keep coming, being passed along, each fully unique.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Eastern mezze to be shared at Sarma

paragraphs.text:
A sarma is a very popular Eastern mezze, quite similar to the dolmas, except vine leaves are replaced with cabbage and stuffed with cooked rice. In the Boston periphery of Somerville, the idea of serving sarma transformed into a full-fledged restaurant of the same name, where all sorts of small dishes are to be shared by patrons. This is where to find mezze born from the fusion of Mediterranean, Turkish and Middle Eastern cuisines.

The look of the place is reminiscent of a bistro, with exposed brick walls, bargain-hunted chairs and bottle-green bench seats. The Eastern aspect can be felt up to the ceilings, carrying vintage serrated Eastern chandeliers. Served in enamelled stoneware, dishes prove surprising and offer innovative textures. As a family or with friends, try in turn the lamb köfte sliders (Turkish meatballs), the barbecued duck in harissa, or the Tunisian-style beef tartare served with some radish and a soft-boiled egg. That is, with a load of homemade sarmas of course!

Sarma
249 Pearl Street
Somerville,MA 02145

+1 617 764 4464

https://sarmarestaurant.com//

Menu: around 29 USD

content.title: Class and refinement at Freepoint Hotel West Cambridge

introduction.small: The Freepoint Hotel West Cambridge happens to be a haven of rest, only a few miles from Boston's city centre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Class and refinement at Freepoint Hotel West Cambridge

paragraphs.text:
This magnificent independent hotel is located in West Cambridge, in the Fresh Bond neighbourhood. The decoration aims to surprise at all times, alternating between works of art and new technology. While the lobby gives off a chic and industrial feel thanks to kinetic and 3D installations, the 121 bedrooms are on the cutting edge of comfort and modernity. The walls are adorned in pared-down tones, while the pieces of art displayed here and there bring out a pleasing sense of originality. Most of the furniture has been produced in the region. It is different in every room, using a variety of shapes and colours that makes every piece totally unique.
If you feel a little hungry, head over to Freepoint Kitchen + Cocktails, run by chef Matthew Gaudet. His dishes – artichoke dips, olive and fig tapenade or half-chicken roasted in herbs – are just as carefully thought out as the cocktails - to be enjoyed in moderation - that you will be able to enjoy on the fabulous patio, amid greenery.

Freepoint Hotel West Cambridge
220 Alewife Brook Pkwy
Cambridge, MA 02138

+1 617 491 8000

www.freepointhotel.com

Rooms: from 179 USD

content.title: Smoke Shop BBQ, Boston's true institution

introduction.small: Barbecue is a tradition inherited from the southern American states. Smoke Shop BBQ respects all its codes and puts Boston on the map as a must-go-to.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Smoke Shop BBQ, Boston's true institution

paragraphs.text:
With three restaurants opened in the space of two years, Andy Husbands' recipe proved successful. In the Assembly Row shopping centre, his latest establishment opened in July 2018 confirmed an established reputation: the choice of meats, cooking methods, selection and quality of wood used to prepare the barbecue, as well as the atmosphere itself are just some of the reasons you absolutely have to try it. The spanking new loft space uses the brand's signature materials, namely raw timber and stone.
You will thus take a seat under the high ceilings and revel in Texas-inspired cuisine: the best pork chops, brisket, smoked turkey and famous spicy chicken wings await your order. Vegetarian and gluten-allergic patrons will also be delighted to find smoked tofu, cornbread and fried cauliflower as possible options on the menu.
However, the chef's proposed BBQ experience will not be complete without a gulp of whisky, of which you will find one of the largest selections of the entire region. To be enjoyed in moderation, as one would expect!

Smoke Shop BBQ Kendall Square
1 Kendall Square
Cambridge, MA 02139

Smoke Shop BBQ Seaport
343 Congress Street
Boston, MA 02210

Smoke Shop BBQ Assembly Row
325 Assembly Row
Somerville, MA 02145

Menu: from 16 USD

https://thesmokeshopbbq.com/

content.title: Chickadee, a culinary oasis in the heart of Seaport

introduction.small: Named as a tribute to the famous bird of Massachusetts, Chickadee offers Mediterranean-influenced cuisine crafted with products typical of New England.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chickadee, a culinary oasis in the heart of Seaport

paragraphs.text:
You will be captivated by a feeling of well-being as soon as you walk through the door of Chickadee. Here, huge chandeliers flood the room with a soft light, over large, simple and refined designer furniture. Close to the gigantic raw wood counter, you will see the busy open kitchen run by good-humoured chefs John DaSilva and Ted Kilpatrick, who make a point of working with ingredients from New England farms, markets and producers.
Next to the must-have pasta with clams, one of the house specialities, the marinated beetroot, served with pistachios, goat cheese and ras el-hanout, or the grilled Colorado lamb served with artichokes and a mint salad are also essential signature dishes. For dessert, indulge in the must-try carrot cake, topped with coconut, pineapple and dates. As for beverages, the drink menu, with a selection of beers and ciders produced by small local businesses, was created with the utmost attention - to be consumed with moderation. With Chickadee, a Mediterranean wind is blowing over Boston.

Chickadee
21 Dry Dock Avenue
Boston, MA 02210

+1 617 531 5591

www.chickadeerestaurant.com

Menu: from 34 USD

content.title: Asta, the culinary reference of Boston

introduction.small: The Asta restaurant is a Boston version of the famous Noma. Dishes are to be admired before being tasted. The menus are perfectly composed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Asta, the culinary reference of Boston

paragraphs.text:
Alex Crabb was deeply inspired by the Copenhagen Noma, a temple to gastronomy for the entire world, during his apprenticeship there. Building on this Danish experience, the chef has made the Asta restaurant into a must for all of Boston. The decor is industrial, with red brick walls, light-coloured wood tables and chairs straight out of a classroom. The open kitchen lets you admire the dexterity of the cooks who prepare your meal right in front of you. You can choose between two tasting menus that contain five or eight dishes, each consisting exclusively of seasonal products and fresh ingredients. Enjoy the pheasant served with black truffles and celery, or a fillet of cod with capers and shallots. For dessert, opt for the cherry soufflé, served with its cardamom marshmallow.

Asta
47 Massachusetts Avenue
Boston, MA 02115

+1 617 585 9575

www.astaboston.com

Menu: from 80 USD

content.title: A few glasses and some paint at The Paint Bar

introduction.small: Inspired by a concept created in Atlanta, The Paint Bar in Boston was inaugurated in 2010 and welcomes more and more apprentice artists as it has become better known.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A few glasses and some paint at The Paint Bar

paragraphs.text:
Drinking and painting at the same time is the credo of a Boston spot located a few steps from the Charles River. After several years, the owners of The Paint Bar can now boast of having worked with more than 30,000 men, women and children from all artistic backgrounds... including some total neophytes. Creativity is explored in community in an atmosphere conducive to aesthetic and inventive encounters.

To celebrate an event with office colleagues, for a surprise birthday for toddlers, to impress a girlfriend or simply to spend some pleasant time, come here to free your wildest ideas with a glass of wine or beer at hand. The Paint Bar introduces painting to the people of Boston, tourists and the ever curious: they provide you with all the necessary material. So pick up your brush and paint!

The Paint Bar
248 Newbury Street
Boston, MA 02116

+1 617 467 5777

www.thepaintbar.com

Between 25 and 45 USD a painting session

content.title: At the Mistral, a French wind is blowing in Boston

introduction.small: Chef Jamie Mammano invites you on a journey to taste the savours of the Mediterranean, without ever leaving Boston ...

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: At the Mistral, a French wind is blowing in Boston

paragraphs.text:
In rapidly evolving Boston, the Mistral has remained true to itself since its inception in 1997 by chef Jamie Mammano. Everything is done to take you away, metaphorically of course, to the French coast. The name 'Mistral' evokes the wind that blows over the south of France. The decoration transports you to Provence with its pottery, wooden furniture, chandeliers and especially its imposing clock with Roman numerals which, at lunch time, invites you to sit at one of the tables.

Just like the decor, the cooking is simple but delicious, all the more so thanks to the seasonal products. Enjoy a sole meunière with lemon and capers, served with sautéed spinach and potatoes, or a half duck roast and wild mushroom risotto. These captivating Mediterranean dishes almost make you hear the sweet song of the cicadas.

Mistral
223 Columbus Avenue
Boston, MA 02116

+1 617 867 9300

https://mistralbistro.com/

Menu: around 55 USD

content.title: Duck Tours, from earth to sea

introduction.small: How about boarding a vehicle with an unusual style? Half bus, half boat, it advances through the city, crossing districts and sliding on rivers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Duck Tours, from earth to sea

paragraphs.text:
You may have already seen them on the streets of London, Singapore or Miami. They look like elegant six-wheeled boats. Boats with wheels? Yes, six wheels capable of guiding the vehicle through Boston with tours starting at the Prudential Center, the Museum of Science and the New England Aquarium. The drivers of the "Duck Tours", these amphibious buses, are even known as conducktors and are as comfortable in the avenues of the metropolis as on the waters of the Charles River.

Determined to try it out, you embark on your very own bus-boat for a complete tourist circuit: New Old South Church, Beacon Hill, Longfellow Bridge, Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy Greenway, King's Chapel, John Hancock Tower, TD Garden... The most beautiful monuments and districts of Boston will pass before your eyes, and you can be amazed by the changing scenes of Boston, from its picturesque street lights at the seaside to colonial vestiges from another time.

+1 617 450 0068

www.bostonducktours.com

content.title: On the trail of Boston's ghosts

introduction.small: As the sun sets over Boston, ghosts of the past emerge from a gloomy alley, in the rooms of a famous hotel and in the heart of a dark cemetery.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: On the trail of Boston's ghosts

paragraphs.text:
Ghosts & Gravestones is a company bent on unveiling Boston's most terrifying mysteries. With legends told by the tour hosts, you let yourself be drawn, slowly but surely, into a sinister past troubled by wars and the bloody murders of Jolly Jane, John Webster and Cotton Mather. As one of North America's oldest cities, the capital of Massachusetts has excitement and horror to offer.

From stories of drowning in the frozen waters of its harbour to the sordid stories of its landfills, Boston's night awakens to the footsteps of its phantoms. As you board the squeaky tramway greeted by a former gravedigger, the murmurs of the city's famous strangler invade your attentive ear. A particularly successful celebration of the supernatural!

Ghosts & Gravestones
200 Atlantic Avenue
Boston, MA 02110

+1 866 754 9136

www.ghostsandgravestones.com/boston

content.title: Mr. Bartley's: an American institution

introduction.small: Any Bostonian will tell you Mr. Bartley's burgers are the best in the city. This love story has lasted for more than 50 years.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mr. Bartley's: an American institution

paragraphs.text:
You have to go to Harvard to get to know the quintessential American sandwich, the hamburger. Mr. Bartley's produces the best in Boston. This typical diner has been the favourite of college students and celebrities for half a century: Johnny Cash, Jackie Onassis, Bob Dylan, Joan Baez, and Al Pacino have all had a burger here.

The recipe for this family success is relatively simple: meat of incomparable freshness, cooked to perfection, cooked onions, and 30 different combinations of toppings, each a nod and a wink to an American icon. You can choose from the Obama and the Donald Trump to the Beyoncé and the iPhone burger…

Mr. Bartley's
1246 Massachusetts Ave
Cambridge, MA 02138

+1 617 354 6559

www.mrbartley.com

Menu: around 16,50 USD

content.title: The Copley House: a relaxing spot in Back Bay

introduction.small: A hotel/private apartment that is hospitable and reasonably priced, The Copley House makes Back Bay accessible.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Copley House: a relaxing spot in Back Bay

paragraphs.text:
At the heart of Back Bay, close to iconic Copley Place and Newbury Street, Copley House is centrally located. Its beautiful bright rooms open onto the surrounding cityscape. They are simple, bringing together wood, bright fabrics, and a palette of contemporary colours.

After a day visiting Boston, relax in a cosy and comfortable atmosphere. All rooms have a small kitchen, and a private or shared bathroom. There is free parking and pets are allowed. In a city with few places that are this appealing, affordable, and conveniently located, The Copley House, with its low prices and warm hospitality, is a great find.

The Copley House
239 W Newton Street
Boston, MA 02116

+1 617 236 8300

www.copleyhouse.com

Rooms: from 99 USD

content.title: Boston Public Library: architectural and archival riches

introduction.small: Inspired by the Italian Renaissance, the Boston Public Library is one of Boston's true architectural jewels

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Boston Public Library: architectural and archival riches

paragraphs.text:
At Copley Square in Back Bay, a handful of 18th- and 19th-century monuments, including the Boston Public Library, seem to rub up against the glass buildings that surround them. Behind its bronze doors, the majestic Boston Public Library's grandiose staircases and long corridors are lined in marble and exceptional frescoes. Push open the doors of the ornately ceilinged study rooms, which are always shrouded in a studious silence.

The Boston Public Library has an impressive collection of roughly 16 million books and manuscripts, and a splendid collection of photographs, drawings, and engravings by Daumier, Rembrandt, Toulouse-Lautrec, and Goya. To complete the site visit in style, go to the Courtyard Restaurant for afternoon tea overlooking the pretty Italianate courtyard.

Boston Public Library
700 Boylston Street
Boston, MA 02116

+1 617 536 5400

www.bpl.org

content.title: Island Creek Oyster Bar: from sea to plate

introduction.small: Island Creek Oyster Bar is one of Boston's most popular seafood restaurants.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Island Creek Oyster Bar: from sea to plate

paragraphs.text:
In just a few years, Island Creek Oyster Bar has become one of the top seafood restaurants in the city. This trendy Boston oyster bar is helmed by the multi-award-winning Jeremy Sewall, a fisherman's son who brings out the best in New England seafood like no other. Whether served at table or at the raw bar, Maine lobsters share the spotlight with a dozen oyster varieties, Jonah crabs, and clams.

Sewall does his own reinterpretations of New England classics like tasty lobster roll. The stunning setting adds to the experience, with its wall of oyster shells. For a more relaxed and informal setting, the same group's Row 34 is a neo-brasserie with brick walls and local craft beers.

Island Creek Oyster Bar
500 Commonwealth Avenue
Boston, MA 02215

+1 617 532 5300

www.islandcreekoysterbar.com

Menu: around 45 USD

content.title: XV Beacon: a well-kept secret

introduction.small: This discreetly luxurious ‘Pied à terre' for discerning globetrotters is hidden in Boston's historic area.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: XV Beacon: a well-kept secret

paragraphs.text:
At the corner of a street in Beacon Hill, flanked by elegant, perfectly maintained Victorian townhouses, is the XV Beacon. With its undeniable cachet, this ten-storey Art Nouveau jewel has 63 rooms whose anti-show-off luxury and excellence combine to produce the very definition of ‘WASP'. There are only seven rooms per floor for added privacy. Kiehl's amenities and luxury Italian bed linens reinforce the sense of intimacy and chic detail.
At Mooo Restaurant, the same modernity is extended to the classic menu. And should you wish to leave this leisurely retreat, the hotel also has on hand two chic Lexus vehicles and drivers for hotel guests.

XV Beacon Hotel
15 Beacon Street
Boston, MA 02108

+1 617 670 1500

https://xvbeacon.com

Rooms: from 417 USD

content.title: The Institute of Contemporary Art: Boston's cultural cutting-edge

introduction.small: Opened in 2006, the ICA provides a backdrop to local talent and positions Boston as a major player on the contemporary art scene.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Institute of Contemporary Art: Boston's cultural cutting-edge

paragraphs.text:
The Institute of Contemporary Art on Fan Pier has given new life to Boston. Its spectacular glass architecture, designed by Diller Scofidio + Renfro, seems to disappear into the water. Inside, the vast spaces bathed in natural light showcase avant-garde works by Thomas Hirschhorn, Cindy Sherman, Louise Bourgeois, Rineke Dijkstra, Marlene Dumas, Nan Goldin, and Mona Hatoum, among many others. The presence of so many female artists is explained by a donation: The Barbara Lee Collection of Art by Women. The ICA's temporary exhibitions—solo artists or thematic shows—are of exceptionally high quality. And the views of Boston Harbor from the top floor are equally stunning.

Institute of Contemporary Art (ICA)
25 Harbor Shore Drive
Boston, MA 02210

+1 617 478 3100

www.icaboston.org

content.title: Symphony Hall: the finest in the USA

introduction.small: Home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the famous Boston Pops, Symphony Hall is considered, acoustically, one of the three best concert halls in the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Symphony Hall: the finest in the USA

paragraphs.text:
For classical music lovers, Boston's Symphony Hall is a must. Built in 1900, this vast concert hall of more than 2,000 seats was inspired by the Leipzig Gewandhaus, but it was endowed with something entirely new: modern acoustics. The proximity of Harvard, and Berklee Music College, just a block away, is of course no accident. Beethoven is the only name inscribed above the stage (the founders couldn't agree on anyone else) but Ravel, Mahler, Mozart etc. get their fair share of play. Attend a concert during the famous Pops Spring and Holiday seasons, when extra tables are added on the main floor. It's an unforgettable experience.

Symphony Hall
301 Massachusetts Avenue
Boston, MA 02115

+1 617 266 1492

www.bso.org

content.title: The Lenox: prestige and old-world style

introduction.small: The charmingly old-fashioned Lenox transports you to turn-of-the-century Boston, a time when the art of hospitality was at its highest point.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Lenox: prestige and old-world style

paragraphs.text:
Built in 1900 by a relative of Winston Churchill and the Duke of Windsor, and just steps away from the Boston Public Library, The Lenox quickly became an institution in Boston. Behind its Italian Renaissance-inspired facade are 214 rooms and suites in old European style with mahogany furniture and crystal chandeliers. The hotel's warm and cosy atmosphere has attracted many celebrity guests over the decades, including Judy Garland, George W. Bush, Michelle Pfeiffer, John Travolta, John Kerry, and Anne Hathaway. The list is long, and it contributes to the Lenox's sense of mystery and legend. Besides an award-winning restaurant, the hotel also has a gym. If you prefer your workouts to take place outdoors, bicycle rentals are on offer.

The Lenox Hotel
61 Exeter Street
Boston, MA 02116

+1 617 536 5300

www.lenoxhotel.com

Rooms: from 235 USD

content.title: Island hopping in Boston Bay

introduction.small: On sunny days, the gorgeous maritime landscapes of the bay islands provide glorious escape.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Island hopping in Boston Bay

paragraphs.text:
From the waterfront of Boston, you can see dotted before you 34 islands on the immediate horizon. If the weather is good, a day-long cruise is in order. The Boston Harbor Islands ferry, which services the main islands, is a good place to start. Highlights on this trip include Little Brewster Island, home to the oldest lighthouse in the United States, and Peddocks Island, where Martin Scorsese shot Shutter Island.

On George Island, you can visit Fort Warren, and Spectacle Island offers hiking, yoga lessons, and sea-kayak excursions. Finally, join the many Bostonians who throng to Lovells Island for an ocean dip on its lovely beaches.

Boston Harbor Cruises Ferry Center
66 Long Wharf
Boston, MA 02110

+1 617 227 4321

www.bostonharborislands.org

content.title: Newbury Street, shopping nirvana

introduction.small: The most famous street in Boston is one of the country's best shopping destinations.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Newbury Street, shopping nirvana

paragraphs.text:
Newbury Street is Boston's top shopping street. The epicentre of the very chic Back Bay neighbourhood, this two-mile or eight-block-long street is the most emblematic in the city. Its 19th-century brownstone buildings, with their long bow windows and small gardens, and the proximity of Boston's large green areas, give it a unique atmosphere.

Here, independent boutiques and vintage shops share space with major US and international brands. Chanel, Hermes, Madewell, and American Apparel are all present and accounted for, and J. Crew and Gucci are just around the corner. There are also numerous art galleries, third-wave coffee shops, and trendy restaurants.

Newbury Street
Boston, MA 02116

www.newbury-st.com

content.title: The MFA: a treasure trove of art

introduction.small: From ancient Egypt to the Impressionists, the impressive collections of the Museum of Fine Arts (MFA) span centuries and continents.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The MFA: a treasure trove of art

paragraphs.text:
Located north of Fenway, not far from the exceptional Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, the Museum of Fine Arts is a more classical style of museum. As one of the most important museums in the US, it certainly deserves a visit. Rich collections of Ancient Egyptian, Asian, European, and American art are yours to discover inside this giant building flanked by 19th-century colonnades. The Japanese collection is the largest in the world outside of Japan. The European collection, however, is the most impressive, with its many masterworks by Cézanne, Monet, Manet, Renoir, Van Gogh, and Bosch. Among the priceless pieces is Gauguin's Where Do We Come From? What Are We? Where Are We Going? First-rate temporary exhibitions round out the visit.

Museum of Fine Arts (MFA)
465 Huntington Avenue
Boston, MA 02115

+1 617 267 9300

www.mfa.org

content.title: Bodega: the clandestine boutique

introduction.small: In the heart of Back Bay hides the most unusual and best-known shop in Boston.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bodega: the clandestine boutique

paragraphs.text:
If you passed in front of Bodega, you probably wouldn't stop, except maybe for coffee or a box of cereal. Because, at first glance, Bodega looks like just another anonymous convenience store, filled with the usual staples. But… the soda machine in the back of the shop is actually a secret door that opens onto one of the world's most influential ‘street-cred' boutiques. Inside, the rarest and the most advanced Adidas and Vans Supra share the spotlight with Bodega creations and capsule collections created in collaboration with major brands, along with a selection of ready-to-wear streetwear, books, accessories, and designer objects.

Bodega
6 Clearway Street
Boston, MA 02115

http://shop.bdgastore.com

content.title: Mei Mei: tasty fusion

introduction.small: From Little Italy to Chinatown, Boston reveals a mixed palate and a range of surprising flavours. With Mei Mei, American and Chinese culinary art combine for a contemporary result.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mei Mei: tasty fusion

paragraphs.text:
Mei Mei is run by a Chinese-American brother and sister. This double culture plunges the restaurant headlong into a hotpot of gastronomy. In 2012, they ran a food truck, showcasing local New England produce. Unanimously acclaimed, the young chefs decided to open a restaurant, keeping to the principles of fresh ingredients and flash preparation. Their creative half-Chinese, half-American cuisine has been a roaring success with Boston food connoisseurs since 2013. The restaurant sparkles with bright yellow chairs and the menu sparkles too, with hybrid delights like three sisters dumplings (Chinese ravioli stuffed with beans, corn and black pepper jelly), a curry of sweet potatoes and a porco rosso (pulled pork, shiitake mushrooms and cranberry).

Mei Mei
506 Park Dr
Boston, MA 02215

+1 857 250 4959

www.meimeiboston.com

Menu: around 14 USD

content.title: The JFK Library

introduction.small: JFK's life and fate touched the hearts of all Americans, but he is the subject of special worship in the city of his birth.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The JFK Library

paragraphs.text:
The JFK Library pays tribute to one of the most famous of Bostonians. Designed by renowned architect IM Pei, a graduate of MIT and Harvard, its pure lines seem to echo those of the ocean. Here, as the 35th President of the United States was fond of saying, 'we commemorate the past by illuminating the future'. Historical objects, some of which were bequeathed by Jackie Onassis, as well as video and audio documents trace the President's life and the way he marked an era. The chronologically organised exhibits are stimulating and entertaining-a storefront in 1960, excerpts from television debates, and a replica of the Oval Office evoke the great moments of a life cut short. In a darkened hallway, archival images of the announcement of JFK's death are particularly moving. A very poignant pilgrimage.

John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum
Columbia Point
Boston, MA 02125

+1 617 514 1569

www.jfklibrary.org/

content.title: SoWa: a bohemian market in South End

introduction.small: The Sunday market in one of the trendiest neighbourhoods of Boston provides the perfect blend of fashionable clothing and cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: SoWa: a bohemian market in South End

paragraphs.text:
The old industrial factories and warehouses in the South End now house trendy shops and artist studios. Every Sunday from May to October, between from 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., local and trendy Bostonians come here to attend the large outdoor market on Harrison Avenue. Get your fruit and veg here at the farmer's market. The seasonal produce is artfully arranged in wooden boxes or on pieces of burlap. Next door, you can hunt for designer jewellery, vintage clothing and accessories, and original deco objects. Then, head to the food trucks, which offer no shortage of tantalising gourmet delicacies.

SoWa Open Market
460 Harrison Avenue

content.title: Drink: tailor-made cocktails

introduction.small: Voted best cocktail bar in the world at the Spirits Competition 2013, Drink pushes the limits, offering sensory experiences and handcrafted tastes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Drink: tailor-made cocktails

paragraphs.text:
Barbara Lynch's cocktail bar is in a former Fort Point wool warehouse. She is the only female chef in the Relais & Châteaux group in North America, and helms seven well-known gourmet restaurants in Boston. It's no wonder that she views the cocktail shaker as a culinary art in itself, inspired by Prohibition and cocktail's oldest recipes. There's no menu at this large bar or in its cosier spots, only chic snacks. Prompted by whatever you feel like at the moment, the bartender concocts a subtle mixture, blending brilliantly infused elixirs and handpicked ingredients. Drink is an adventure, and perfect for those who want a one-of-a-kind experience.

content.title: In search of Moby Dick

introduction.small: Who has not dreamt of crossing paths with one of these majestic marine mammals?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In search of Moby Dick

paragraphs.text:
Off Boston's coast, in Massachusetts Bay, the waters of the Stellwagen Bank National Marine Sanctuary teem with plankton and other sea creatures, which attract many whale species. They feed here for several months, before heading to warmer waters.

From the port, a three-hour cruise by catamaran will bring you face to face with Minke whales, humpbacks, pilot whales, rorquals, and other black whales. The spectacle of these huge mammals is utterly fascinating. The naturalists from the New England Aquarium on board will answer all your questions. A truly unique experience, from March to mid-November (several departures per day).

content.title: Element Boston Seaport, environmentally minded

introduction.small: Exploring Boston without leaving an excessive carbon footprint is possible in this stylish eco-friendly hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Element Boston Seaport, environmentally minded

paragraphs.text:
In the South Boston district, facing the ocean, Element Boston Seaport is the newest hotel on the seafront. This Starwood group establishment is a hotel with a 'green attitude'. It features 180 eco-friendly, ultra-comfortable rooms with clean lines, airy spaces, and bright and contemporary style. It recycles water and uses low energy equipment and natural materials like soy fabric.

This extends to the dining area. Though all the rooms have a kitchen, the Rise and Restore has a nice selection of healthy and dietary products. This is the perfect base for exploring Boston, whether by complimentary bike or electric car—the hotel has its own charging station.

content.title: Boston seen from the sky at the Prudential Tower

introduction.small: The Prudential Tower, a Boston landmark, has one of the most beautiful views of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Boston seen from the sky at the Prudential Tower

paragraphs.text:
At 230 metres high, the Prudential Tower towers over almost every other skyscraper in Back Bay. Only the Hancock is taller. Built in 1964 to house Prudential Insurance, the Pru has the highest observatory deck in all of New England. The view of Boston from the Skywalk Observatory on the 50th floor is absolutely spectacular. By day, you can see the waves cresting on the Boston Harbor island shoreline, and at dusk, the sunsets are incredible. The audio guides, included in the admission price, provide valuable information. Take the elevator up two more floors to the Top of the Hub restaurant, which serves excellent wines and an even more magnificent view.

content.title: The Beehive, Boston's jazz central

introduction.small: Discover the rich Boston jazz scene at The Beehive, a restaurant-cum-jazz club with a chic, whimsical atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Beehive, Boston's jazz central

paragraphs.text:
At the heart of the Boston Center for the Arts, the Beehive offers a bohemian atmosphere with great jazz and cabaret programming. Its name comes from La Ruche, the iconic artist studio in Montparnasse in Paris, a hangout for many artists in the 20s, including Chagall and Léger.

The Beehive is a fashionable café des artistes, featuring live music almost every night of the week. The restaurant menu offers duck à l'orange, vegetarian curry or cheeseburgers, not mentioning oysters of the day, fried calamari and a cauliflower steak, all of which go well with wines from all over the world.

content.title: Loews Boston: casual chic

introduction.small: An ideal location, a sharp but easy-going sense of style, a nice restaurant with terrace, and a storied past: this is a good place to stay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Loews Boston: casual chic

paragraphs.text:
In Back Bay, behind the beautiful early 20th-century facade of the former headquarters of the Boston Police Department, is the Loews. Handcuffs and batons have been left far behind. All that remains is the original woodwork in the lobby and lounge. At the bar, jail cell bars have given way to metro-style tiles. Contemporary and stylish, the 225 rooms and suites are effortlessly comfortable. The restaurant, Precinct Kitchen, is a trendy neo-brasserie with leather seats and a menu that gives new impetus to traditional New England cuisine. In fine weather, the terrace, which is protected from street traffic, is a real asset.

content.title: Beacon Hill: the charm of old Boston

introduction.small: Across from Boston Common, on the hill of the Massachusetts State House, Beacon Hill is the elegant and historic soul of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Beacon Hill: the charm of old Boston

paragraphs.text:
Even if it is mainly residential, Beacon Hill, one of the oldest neighbourhoods in Boston, is a must for anyone who wants to capture the essence of the city. Start with a stroll past the antique shops on Charles, the main street. The storefronts look just like they did in yesteryear. The same is true of the cobblestone streets winding up the hill, which concentrates the bulk of the district. Lined with impeccably well-kept Victorian houses and antique gaslights, they have resisted the wear and tear of the decades with imperturbable charm.

The quiet that reigns today was not always the case. Beacon Hill was a battleground for civil rights. Visit the museum devoted to this tumultuous period of African-American history, before catching the Freedom Trail, which will take you past ochre facades topped by the gilded dome of the Massachusetts State House.

content.title: Jogging on Boston Common

introduction.small: Follow in the footsteps of Boston Marathoners in the bucolic and relaxing Boston Common.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jogging on Boston Common

paragraphs.text:
Boston has its Celtics, Bruins, and Red Sox but at its heart it is a running town, most notably along the banks of the Charles River. Yet lace up and head instead to Boston Common, facing Beacon Hill, to the oldest park in the capital of Massachusetts. Dear to the heart of Bostonians, its 20 hectares contain wooded areas, flower gardens, vast lawns, and Frog Pond, a popular spot for watching wading birds. Along its pleasant paths, you'll be joined by many joggers training for the renowned Boston Marathon, the oldest in the world. If you're not too winded, continue as far as the adjacent Public Garden, where you can rent swan-shaped paddleboats on a lovely pond bordered by weeping willows.

Boston Common

content.title: The amazing Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum

introduction.small: Tucked away in the southwest of Boston, the poetic Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum is worth visiting for its master paintings and unique atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The amazing Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum

paragraphs.text:
Isabella Stewart was unlike any of her 19th-century contemporaries. The unconventional behaviour and tastes of this wealthy New York heiress, who settled in Boston after her marriage in 1860, regularly put her name in the gossip columns. An inspired art collector, she left behind an extraordinary museum, every bit as eccentric and endearing as she herself was. In a small palace of Venetian inspiration overlooking a beautiful garden, Stewart Gardner gathered paintings by masters such as Sargent, Whistler, Fra Angelico, Turner, and Delacroix. But surprisingly, there are no labels next to the paintings. The heiress wanted her guests to enjoy the masterpieces personally, without influence. Today, things remain unchanged. Even frames left empty by a burglary, 25 years ago, seem to await the return of the works. The only thing new here is the extension by Renzo Piano, which houses an exhibition on the history of this small and delightful museum.

content.title: Union Oyster House: a legend

introduction.small: There are oyster bars on practically every street corner in Boston. But if you can only go to one, make it the Union.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Union Oyster House: a legend

paragraphs.text:
Welcome to the oldest restaurant in Boston... and the United States! Suffice to say that this is an absolute must. This temple of gastronomy opened on the Boston Freedom Trail in 1826. Since then, it has continued to serve the Shore Dinner, the traditional New England meal. There's also its famous cream clam chowder, oysters, a fillet of grilled salmon, potato-crusted haddock, lobster ravioli… Authenticity and simplicity are the hallmarks of this great multi-award-winning restaurant, loved by Bostonians and visitors alike. Ask for table 18, where the Kennedys always sat-they were diehard fans of this legendary establishment.

content.title: Cambridge, home of Harvard and MIT

introduction.small: The legendary universities of Cambridge, just across the Charles River, are an intrinsic part of Boston's identity and prestige.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cambridge, home of Harvard and MIT

paragraphs.text:
Head north to the internationally renowned campus of Harvard, the oldest university in the United States, designed on the English model and prefaced by the famous Harvard Yard. Some of the Yard's architectural treasures date back to the 17th century. Holden Chapel, the Widener Library, Matthews Hall, University Hall, the J. Harvard statue—the look and feel is right out of Harry Potter's Hogwarts.

For contrast, move on to the Carpenter Center for the Visual Arts, a concrete vessel on stilts designed by Le Corbusier. And don't forget to take in the campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), which has its own share of modern and contemporary architectural marvels, including buildings by Frank Gehry, Alvar Aalto, and IM Pei. Located in one of Pei's buildings, the List Visual Arts Center contains stunning works by Sol LeWitt, Dan Flavin, and Anish Kapoor, among many others.

content.title: The Envoy: urban paradise

introduction.small: With its high-fashion decor and a rooftop patio with breezes coming off the sea, The Envoy is a favourite of Bostonians and arty hipsters.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Envoy: urban paradise

paragraphs.text:
Just blocks away from the docks of Boston Seaport, this sleek building of glass and steel houses The Envoy, part of the Marriott group's The Autograph. Resolutely in tune with the times, this hotel has gone for a trendy 1950s atmosphere, breaking with its ultra-contemporary exterior. Large designer retro leather sofas, a palette of masculine colours, a TV mounted on a bike, walls decorated with fonts, and boxer-style robes hanging in the sleek bathroom add to the trendiness.

Outlook Kitchen, with its open kitchen, is a chic bistro. But it is especially the rooftop overlooking the water that has made The Envoy one of Boston's hottest spots. It's the perfect place for a cocktail at sunset.

content.title: The Liberty Hotel: a night behind bars

introduction.small: One of the most luxurious hotels in Boston is housed in a beautifully restored prison. An overnight stay is a unique experience.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Liberty Hotel: a night behind bars

paragraphs.text:
Overlooking the Charles River is a former 19th-century prison turned five-star hotel under the Starwood group. Until 1990, the granite building housed somewhat more constrained guests, like Malcolm X and Frank Abagnale, the latter played by Leonardo DiCaprio in Steven Spielberg's Catch Me If You Can. Today, 298 rooms and luxurious suites in soft, bright colours have replaced the prison cells. But it's still difficult to ignore the building's penitentiary past.
Under the 30-meter-high wooden rotunda in a lobby flanked by tall arched windows are vestiges of prison cells and the original bridges to four floors. There is also many a wink and a nudge about the Liberty Hotel's past: at one of its three restaurants, Clink, the wait staff is dressed in uniforms befitting the theme. And the Alibi bar, located in what used to be a cell for detainees to sober up in-with bars intact-is decorated with pictures of errant celebrities and the reasons for their arrests.

content.title: Learn about US democracy at the Edward M. Kennedy Institute

introduction.small: In the city that saw the birth of the United States of America, a fascinating museum illustrates the mechanics of one of the world's largest and oldest democracies.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Learn about US democracy at the Edward M. Kennedy Institute

paragraphs.text:
Edward Moore ‘Ted' Kennedy, the younger brother of John F. Kennedy and a US senator for 47 years, dreamed of creating a museum that would highlight the importance of democracy and the role of the US Senate. It was finally inaugurated by Barack and Michelle Obama in March 2015, six year's after Kennedy's death. Not far from the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum, this 6,000-sqm building takes visitors on an interactive and immersive journey into the history of the US Senate.

In an identical replica of the US Senate Chamber, slip into the skin of a senator, and, with the aid of a tablet, take part in discussions, negotiations, and voting. The high-tech museum also includes a life-size reproduction of the office of Edward M. Kennedy and a portrait gallery.

content.title: Follow the thread of history on the Freedom Trail

introduction.small: Ingenious markings on the ground allow one to find Boston's most emblematic monuments, intrinsically linked to the history of an entire country.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Follow the thread of history on the Freedom Trail

paragraphs.text:
No city's history is more entwined with that of the United States than Boston. To comprehend this better, follow the Freedom Trail across the city. This four-kilometre trail begins at Boston Common, the oldest park in the United States, home of the Massachusetts State House, where Thomas Jefferson read the Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776.

Then it's on to Park Street Church, where the first speech in favour of the abolition of slavery was made; the Old South Meeting House, the 18th-century church where the Boston Tea Party started; the Old State House Museum, the oldest building in Boston; and Faneuil Hall and Quincy Market, famous for its food stalls. A lobster roll later, proceed to Bunker Hill and its obelisk commemorating the eponymous battle. The USS Constitution concludes this pilgrimage. Do not miss the famous frigate completely restored between 2015 and 2017.

content.title: Battery Wharf Hotel: affordable luxury

introduction.small: On the seafront, the Battery Wharf Hotel is a showcase of comfort and refinement.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Battery Wharf Hotel: affordable luxury

When not being a tourist, unwind at the renowned Exhale Spa or participate in an exclusive yoga session with Boston Harbor in the background...

Best of all, this member of The Leading Hotels of the World has a great restaurant. Battery Wharf Grille offers a cocktail of flavours in which North End, Boston's “Little Italy”, meets with traditional New England recipes. Daring but successful, the gastronomic food tastes even better on a fine day when eaten on the shaded terrace overlooking the water. Enchanting.

content.title: The Boxer, an industrial nest

introduction.small: From North End to South End, Boston is upgrading its neoclassical brick buildings and warehouses. Soak up this industrial aesthetic at The Boxer.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Boxer, an industrial nest

paragraphs.text:
At the heart of Bulfinch Triangle, a stone's throw from North End, Faneuil Hall, and Beacon Hill, The Boxer is an assertively styled four-star boutique. It is in the Flatiron Building, a 19th-century building whose lines evoke a clothes iron, and whose very industrial character is sprinkled with current references. From the hotel's 80 rooms to the restaurant, the ambience is cosy and intimate. The lobby ceiling features an old map of Boston, and there are brick walls, Eames chairs, retro sofas, a grey palette, vintage lighting, and brushed steel. The service is impeccable and attentive. And a chic little snobbery completes the experience: borrow a red bicycle to venture into the neighbourhood.

The Boxer Hotel

content.title: The outside sale lot of the Brattle Book Shop

introduction.small: One of the oldest and largest antiquarian bookshops in America, the Brattle ‘specialises in not specialising'. Three floors and the outside lot can barely contain its books and collectibles.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The outside sale lot of the Brattle Book Shop

paragraphs.text:
As it is home to some of the most important universities in the country, it's no wonder that Boston has very good used bookstores. None tops the Brattle Book Shop. This family-run business near the Boston Common opened in 1825. Since then, its catalogue has considerably expanded, so much so that the original storefront can't hold all the books… so owner Ken Gloss moved out onto the street, appropriating an impasse between two red brick buildings. Books sit on shelves that climb the high walls or in boxes on every available square inch of the ground. In all there are some 250,000 old, rare, and used books, magazines, maps, prints, postcards, and ephemera in the store's inventory. There is something for everyone, guaranteed.

content.title: The Verb: for rock and roll nights

introduction.small: In Fenway, The Verb pays tribute to the Boston music scene. Relive rock's heyday in a delightfully retro setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Verb: for rock and roll nights

paragraphs.text:
Dropkick Murphys, Aerosmith, the Pixies, and New Kids on the Block: Boston is a rock and roll city. In the electric neighbourhood of Fenway, The Verb pays homage to the golden age of rock 'n' roll in the form of a 1959 motel.

A facelift has restored its vintage lustre. The decor includes amplifiers, concert posters, typewriters, Bakelite telephones, and colours and furniture from the 1950s. Organised around a swimming pool and a modernist patio, the 93 rooms evoke an 'American way of life' nostalgia. The Verb also hosts indie concerts in its restaurant, Hojoko. 'Let's rock!'

content.title: Fenway Park: the legendary home of baseball

introduction.small: A Boston Red Sox home game at Fenway is an unforgettable experience

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fenway Park: the legendary home of baseball

paragraphs.text:
At the centre of its eponymous district is Fenway Park, the oldest baseball stadium in the United States. Launched with great fanfare in 1912 for the Boston Red Sox's first game, against the celebrated Yankees, its character hasn't changed much. The scoreboard, for example, up on the famous ‘Green Monster' wall, has been there since 1934, and still has to be manually updated.

The fans in the stands at Fenway are as much of a show as the game on the field. Book tickets well in advance! And who knows, maybe you'll get to sit in the legendary Red Seat, the only red seat in the bleachers, which marks the longest drive ever hit in the stadium's history.

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Boston
content.introduction: Despite its proximity to the Atlantic Ocean, Boston has a temperate continental climate, marked by a large temperature range. Winters are cold and dry (between 0°C/32°F and -10°C/14°F on average), especially from November to March, and snowfall is frequent. Spring is short, followed by a hot and humid summer in July and August. September temperatures are more bearable (20°C/68°F and above).

airports.title: Boston-Logan International Airport
airports.description:
Boston-Logan International Airport is located in East Boston, roughly five kilometres from the city centre.
  • 4 terminals
    • TA
    • TB
    • TC
    • TE (Air France)

Getting from the airport to Boston and back:
  • By car:
    • Accessible via the Massachusetts Turnpike East, the I-93, or the I-95 to Route 1 South. About 20 minutes to reach the city centre.
    • The airport has four car parks. The central car park is within walking distance from all terminals. B and E terminals each have a parking lot. Economy parking is serviced by free shuttle buses to and from all terminals. Prices range from USD 7 for 1 hour to up to USD 26 for 24 hours.
    • Car rental companies are grouped in the Rental Car Center on the other side of the I-90.
  • Bus:
    • The free Silver Line connects the airport with South Station, which is on the Red Line of the subway.
  • Subway:
    • The Blue Line runs from the airport and connects to the Orange and Green lines. To get to Airport Station, take the complimentary shuttles #22 (TA and TB), #33 (TC and TE), and #55 (all terminals), leaving every 5-6 minutes. A subway ticket costs USD 2.75.
  • Water Taxis & Shuttles:
    • The Boston Water Taxi (BWT) goes from the airport to Long Wharf in downtown Boston, and costs USD 10. Massport's complimentary shuttle bus #66 serves all terminals (every 15 minutes) from Logan Dock.
  • Taxi:
    • Taxi fares from the airport cost between USD 25 and USD 45 and about 20 minutes to reach the city centre.
  • Services:
    • Bars and restaurants, souvenirs shops, banks, children's playground, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) in the airport.
    • Website: www.massport.com
    • Telephone: +1 800 235 6426

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Boston
localCalendar.description:
Every year, numerous holidays are celebrated in Boston.
Below are the main dates for these festivities:

events.title: January 18 : Martin Luther King, Jr. Day (national)
events.description: A federal holiday in the United States, celebrating the life and achievements of Martin Luther King, Jr. In recent years, it has increasingly been seen as a day of service, when Americans are encouraged to volunteer to help others less fortunate than themselves. In Boston, exhibitions, gospel concerts, and debates take place at the Museum of African-American History.

events.title: Late January-Early February : Chinese New Year (national)
events.description: Chinese New Year is celebrated annually in Chinatown with a parade and fireworks.

events.title: The weekend before or after 17 March : Saint Patrick's Day Parade (local)
events.description: Colourful floats line the parade route through South Boston, home to one of the largest Irish communities in the United States. Between 600,000 and a million people attend, as Saint Patrick is the city's Patron Saint. A very festive atmosphere!

events.title: Third Monday of April : Patriot's Day (local)
events.description: The Patriot's Day holiday in Massachusetts, Maine, and Wisconsin commemorates the first battle of the American Revolution with re-enactments and performances.

events.title: Third Monday of April : Boston Marathon (local)
events.description: The world's oldest marathon attracts more than 25,000 runners. The 42-kilometre route starts west of Boston in Hopkinton and finishes in front of the Boston Public Library.

events.title: July 4 : Halloween (national)
events.description: A federal holiday in the United States commemorating the adoption of the Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776. Celebrated with parades, military marches and fireworks.

events.title: October 31 : Thanksgiving (national)
events.description: During this national holiday, for many Americans the most important of the year, most Bostonians share a traditional meal with friends and family.

events.title: Fourth Thursday of November : Thanksgiving (national)
events.description: Originally a Christian religious observance, for many years Thanksgiving has been a secular holiday in the United States, celebrated by Americans of all faiths. Families come together to prepare and enjoy a large feast at home. The meal typically includes roast turkey with stuffing, mashed potatoes, cranberry sauce as well as various side dishes and ends with an assortment of pies (pumpkin, pecan, apple).

events.title: December 31 : First Night Boston (local)
events.description: On New Year's Eve, the streets of Boston host concerts, dance performances, street food and art displays.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for the United States.
administrativeProcedures.description:
The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) allows citizens of participating countries to travel to the United States without a visa for stays of 90 days or less, whether for tourism or business. Two requirements must be met:

  • Your passport must meet the criteria for VWP travel (it must be machine-readable, with an integrated chip containing information from the passport data page). For further information, visit the Visa Waiver Program page on the Website of the Bureau of Consular Affairs, U.S. Department of State: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/us-visas/tourism-visit/visa-waiver-program.html
  • You must have a valid Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) prior to travel. For further information, visit the ESTA page on the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Website: https://www.cbp.gov/travel/international-visitors/esta

usefulAddresses.title: Entry requirements for the United States.
usefulAddresses.description:
The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) allows citizens of participating countries to travel to the United States without a visa for stays of 90 days or less, whether for tourism or business. Two requirements must be met:

  • Your passport must meet the criteria for VWP travel (it must be machine-readable, with an integrated chip containing information from the passport data page). For further information, visit the Visa Waiver Program page on the Website of the Bureau of Consular Affairs, U.S. Department of State: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/us-visas/tourism-visit/visa-waiver-program.html
  • You must have a valid Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) prior to travel. For further information, visit the ESTA page on the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Website: https://www.cbp.gov/travel/international-visitors/esta

Travellers not eligible for the VWP, or who have not been able to obtain an ESTA, must apply for a visa.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Boston and the United States, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations.

goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping

In Boston as in the rest of the United States, a service charge is not included in the bill and tips form a major portion of income for waiting staff. Prices on restaurant menus are indicated before taxes and tips. You are therefore expected to leave a tip (generally between 15 and 20 percent of the bill). Tipping less than 15 percent (or leaving no tip at all) means that you are very dissatisfied with the service.
